{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Shrutilayalu | image = Sruthilayalu.jpg | caption = | Producer = Karunakar, Sudhakar | director = [[K. Viswanath]] | writer = K. Viswanath | starring = [[Rajasekhar (actor)|Rajasekhar]]
[[Sumalata]]
[[Shanmukha Srinivas]]
[[Jayalalita]]
[[Naresh (actor)|Naresh]] | music = [[K. V. Mahadevan]] | cinematography = Subba Rao G.V | editing = | released = {{Film date|df=yes|1987}} | country = India | runtime = | language = [[Telugu language|Telugu]] | budget = }} '''''Shrutilayalu''''' is a 1987 [[Telugu cinema|Telugu]] [[drama film|musical drama film]], directed by [[K. Viswanath]]. The film starred [[Rajasekhar (actor)|Rajasekhar]] and [[Sumalata]].[http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/talking-talk-shows/article786784.ece Talking talk shows - The Hindu] The soundtrack was composed by [[K. V. Mahadevan]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0249985/ Shruti Layalu (1987) - IMDb] The film has garnered the [[Nandi Awards]] for [[Nandi Award for Best Feature Film|Best feature film]]; [[Nandi Award for Best Director|Best direction]], and a [[Filmfare Award for Best Director – Telugu]].https://archive.is/ZoiwQ The film was premiered at the [[International Film Festival of India]], and [[Annapurna International School of Film and Media|AISFM Film Festival]].[http://www.aisfm.edu.in/blog/2014/the-films-of-k-viswanath/ The films of K. Viswanath — AISFM Blog] ==Plot== The film revolves around the role of Naidu (Kaikala Satyanarayana), a Carnatic musician and elder son Narayana Murthy (played by Rajasekhar) who starts getting recognized in the world because of the music learned from Naidu and leaves everyone to fall into the worldly pleasures, forgetting his base roots. It is now the duty of Sita, the daughter-in-law of Naidu (wife of Narayana Murthy) to bring these souls on track. The film starts with Mr. Naidu (Satyanarayana), a great fan of music and traditional Indian fine arts. He wants his only son to become a great musician, but unfortunately he loses his son in a car accident. Then he adopts three orphaned street children and teaches them carnatic music so they can make his dream of building and starting an academy of fine arts come true. Sumalata is also a fan of music and loves Mr. Narayana (the oldest adopted son of Naidu). Naidu agrees for them to get married and Naresh, the second son marries a rich girl. Naidu sends the three sons to city to earn sufficient money to start the construction of a Music academy. But all three forget the cause they come for once they get popularity in city and they get addicted to bad habits. They disrespect his father once and Rajasekhar even tries to hit his pregnant wife. All this makes Mr. Naidu send the three sons away from home. Then Sumalata, the daughter-in-law takes the onus to make Mr. Naidu's dream come true. She makes her son a great musician and dancer. After a long time, she returns to the city where her husband lives. There she gets Narayana Murthy to take interest in their son's talents without revealing herself to Narayana Murthy or his brother. Narayana, who doesn't know his son, appreciates his talents well and accepts to teach him music. Sumalata makes the other two sons of Mr. Naidu also to concentrate on music through her son. She teaches them a lesson and they come to the realize what they did wrong. In the end, all the sons come together and meet their father and ask for his forgiveness. He forgives them and they start afresh to try and establish the Music Academy. ==Credits== ===Cast=== * [[Rajasekhar (actor)|Rajasekhar]]... Narayana Murthy * [[Sumalata]]... Sita * [[Kaikala Satyanarayana]]... Naidu * [[Shanmukha Srinivas]]... Srinivas * Murali Krishna... Murali * [[Naresh (actor)|Naresh]]... Shankar * [[Anjali Devi]] * [[Aruna Mucherla|Mucherla Aruna]]... Girija * [[Jayalalitha (actress)|Jayalalita]]... Panchali * [[Mallikarjuna Rao (actor)|Mallikarjuna Rao]] * [[Jit Mohan Mitra]]... Anjaneyulu * [[Potti Prasad]] * [[Sakshi Ranga Rao]]... Ramadasu * [[Vankayala Satyanarayana]] * [[Sanjay Vadapalli]] ===Crew=== * Director : [[K. Viswanath]] * Writers : [[K. Viswanath]] (screenplay and story) * Producers : Karunakar, Sudhakar * Original Music : [[K. V. Mahadevan]] * Cinematography : [[G. V. Subba Rao]] * Playback singers : [[Vani Jairam]], [[S. Janaki]], [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], [[P. Susheela]], [[K. J. Yesudas]] * Assistant composer : [[Puhalendi]] * Choreography : [[K. V. Satyanarayana]] * Production Companies : Sudarshan Cine Enterprises ==Songs== * "Aalokaye Shree Bala" (Singer: [[Vani Jayaram]]) * "Inni Rasula Yuniki" (Singers: [[S. P. Balasubrahmanyam]], Vani Jayaram) * "Janaki Kanta Smaranam" (Singer: S. P. Balasubrahmanam) * "Korina Chinnadi" (Singer: Purnachander) * "Mera Jhoota" (Singer: [[S. Janaki]]) * "Shri Gananatham" (Singers: Purnachander, Vani Jayaram) * "Shri Saradamba" (Singer: Janaki) * "Taka Tika" (Singer: Purnachander) * "Tandanaana" (Singer: S. P. Balasubrahmanyam) * "Telavarademo Swamy" (Singer: [[Yesudas]]) * "Telavarademo Swamy" (Singer: [[P. Susheela]]) * "Thanadhu varasatvam" (Singer: [[P. Susheela]]) ==Awards== {{awards table}} |- | rowspan="5"|1987 | rowspan="5"|[[K. Vishwanath]] | [[Nandi Award for Best Feature Film]] - Golden Nandi | {{won}} |- | [[Nandi Award for Best Director]] | {{won}} |- | [[Nandi Award for Best Actress]] - [[Sumalatha]] | {{won}} |- |[[Nandi Award for Best Choreographer]] - K. V. Satyanarayana | {{won}} |- | [[Nandi Award for Best Lyrics - "Telavarademo Swami"]] - [[Sirivennela Sitaramasastri]] | {{won}} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0249985}} {{Kasinathuni Viswanath}} [[Category:1987 films]] [[Category:Indian films]] [[Category:Indian musical films]] [[Category:Films about classical music and musicians]] [[Category:Telugu-language films]] [[Category:Films about the arts]] [[Category:Indian romantic musical films]] [[Category:Indian romance films]] [[Category:Films directed by K. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Leighton-Stitching the Standard.jpg | image_size = 225px | title=Stitching the Standard | artist=[[Edmund Leighton]] | year=1911 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=98 | width_metric=44 | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city = [[Private collection]] }} '''''Stitching the Standard''''' is a painting by British artist [[Edmund Leighton]]. It depicts a nameless damsel on the [[battlement]]s of a medieval castle making the finishing touches to a standard or pennant with a black eagle on a gold background. In a time of peace the woman has taken her needlework into the daylight away from the bustle of the castle.
The painting represents late [[Pre-Raphaelitism]], when life was untarnished by [[World War I]]. ''Stitching the Standard'' is probably listed as ''The Device'' by Leighton's biographer Alfred Yockney among the pictures from 1911.<ref name="Sotheby's">{{cite web | url =http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/lot.pdf.L11133.html/f/51/L11133-51.pdf| title =Victorian & Edwardian Art|publisher =[[Sotheby's]]|date=15 November 2011| accessdate = 28 June 2014}}</ref>
==Provenance== On 23 April 1928 the painting appeared at [[Christie's]] under the title '''''Preparing the Flag''''' and was bought by W. W. Sampson.<ref name="Sotheby's"/> On 26 September 1977, as '''''Awaiting his Return''''', it was bought by Richard Green at [[Phillips (auctioneers)|Phillips]].<ref name="Sotheby's"/> On 27 June 1978, as ''Stitching the Standard'', the painting was sold at [[Sotheby's]] in [[Belgravia]] to a private collector.<ref name="Sotheby's"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1911 paintings]] [[Category:History paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Edmund Leighton]] [[Category:Women in art]] [[Category:Pre-Raphaelite paintings]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox Artwork |title=The Farmers' Lunch |image_file =Diego Velázquez 005.jpg |artist=[[Diego Velázquez]] |other_language_1=[[Spanish language|Spanish]] |other_title_1=Almuerzo de campesinos |year= 1618 |medium=Oil on canvas |height_metric=96 |width_metric=112 |metric_unit=cm |imperial_unit=in |museum=[[Museum of Fine Arts (Budapest)|Museum of Fine Arts]] |city=[[Budapest]] }} '''''The Farmers' Lunch''''' (''Almuerzo de campesinos'') is one of the earliest paintings by the [[Spain|Spanish]] artist [[Diego Velázquez]]. Painted in oil on canvas in 1618, it combines a [[still life]] of food and drink with a depiction of three comic farmers, whose [[physiognomy]] the artist studies closely. The composition shows a younger man gesturing with his right hand to reinforce the story coming from his half-open lips, and an older man listening attentively while holding his cup up to a woman so she can refill it with wine. The still life includes fish, bread, a carrot, a lemon, and a copper vessel.
''The Farmers' Lunch'' is nearly identical to another painting by Velázquez, ''[[The Lunch (Velázquez)|The Lunch]]'' (ca. 1617).
{{Diego Velázquez}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Farmers' Lunch, The}} [[Category:1618 paintings]] [[Category:Seville-period Velazquez paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Diego Velázquez]] [[Category:Paintings in Hungary]] [[Category:Paintings of the Museum of Fine Arts (Budapest)]] [[Category:Food and drink paintings]] [[Category:Genre paintings]]

{{about|the European folktale|the novel by Eowyn Ivey|The Snow Child}} '''''The Snow-child''''' is a widespread European folktale,<ref name="ashliman">[[D. L. Ashliman]], ''[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type1362.html The Snow Child: folktales of type 1362]''</ref> found in many medieval tellings.<ref name="lies"/>
It is [[Aarne–Thompson]] type 1362.<ref name="ashliman"/>
==Synopsis== A merchant returns home after an absence of two years to find his wife with a newborn son. She explains one snowy day she swallowed a snowflake while thinking about her husband which caused her to conceive. Pretending to believe, he raises the boy with her until he takes the boy on a trip and sells him into [[slavery]]. On his return, he explains to his wife that the boy melted in the heat.<ref name="fabliau">Nicolas Balachov, (1984). "[https://books.google.com/books?id=HeY9wVDpM80C&pg=PA30. Le developpement des structures narratives du fabliau a la nouvelle]". in Gabriel Bianciotto, Michel Salvat. ''Épopée animale, fable, fabliau''. Publication Univ Rouen Havre. pp. 30-32.. {{ISBN|978-2-13-038255-3}}. </ref>
==Variants== The tale appears in Medieval [[fabliau]]x,<ref name="fabliau"/> and was used in school exercises of rhetoric.<ref name="lies">Jan M. Ziolkowski ''Fairy Tales from Before Fairy Tales: The Medieval Latin Past of Wonderful Lies'' p 42 {{ISBN|9780472033799}}</ref> It first appears in the 11th-century [[Cambridge Songs]].<ref name="lies"/> A Medieval play about the [[Virgin Mary]] has characters disbelieving her story of her pregnancy citing the tale.<ref name="lies"/>
It contrasts to Aarne-Thompson type 703*, [[Snow Maiden]], where a child really has a magical snow-related origin.<ref>[[D. L. Ashliman]], ''[http://www.pitt.edu/~dash/type0703.html The Snow Maiden: foltales of type 703*]''</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Snow-child}} [[Category:Folklore]] [[Category:Fabliaux]] [[Category:European folklore]]

{{Infobox Historic Site | name = Cathedral of St. Lawrence | native_name = Katedrala Sv. Lovre | native_language = Croatian | image = Trogir cathedral 007.jpg | caption = Bell Tower of St. Lawrence | locmapin = Croatia | coordinates = {{coord|43|31|1.5|N|16|15|05|E|display=inline,title}} | location = [[Trogir]], [[Croatia]] | area = {{convert|6.40|ha|abbr=on}} | built = 13th century | architect = | architecture = [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]], [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] | governing_body = | designation1 = WHS | designation1_partof = Historic City of Trogir | designation1_type = Cultural | designation1_criteria = ii, iv | designation1_date = 1997 <small>(21st [[World Heritage Committee|Session]])</small> | designation1_number = [http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/810 810] | designation1_free1value = [[World Heritage Sites in Europe|Europe and North America]] | designation2 = Croatia Cultural | designation2_offname = Katedrala Sv. Lovre | designation2_date = | designation2_number = | designation3 = | designation3_offname = | designation3_date = | designation3_number = }} The '''Cathedral of St. Lawrence''' ({{lang-hr|Katedrala Sv. Lovre}}) is a [[Roman Catholic]] triple-naved [[basilica]] constructed in [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]]-[[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] in [[Trogir]], [[Croatia]]. Since its construction lasted several centuries, it illustrates all the styles that succeeded one another in [[Dalmatia]]. It serves now as the most imposing monument in the city of Trogir.
==History== It was built on the foundations of an [[Early Christianity|Early Christian]] cathedral destroyed in the 12th century during the sack of the town by the [[Saracens]] in 1123. The building of the cathedral began in 1213 and finished during the 17th century. Like the older one, it is also dedicated to St. Lawrence (Sveti Lovro) but it is better known as St. John's Cathedral (Sveti Ivan) after [[John of Trogir|bishop John]], who died in 1111 and stood out for his saintly lifestyle at a time when the Hungarian King Koloman had taken over Dalmatia and Croatia. Most of the work in the construction of the cathedral took place in the 13th century, being largely completed in 1251. That means the building is mainly in Romanesque style, whilst the vault inside is gothic as it was built during the 15th century, in [[Mannerist]] style.
Work on the bell tower began at the end of the 14th century, but it was not completed until the end of the 16th century. The first floor is in Gothic style and was built by Masters Stejpan and Matej. After it had been demolished by the Venetians in 1420, it was restored by Matija Gojković.<ref>Naklada Naprijed, ''The Croatian Adriatic Tourist Guide'', pg. 224, Zagreb (1999), {{ISBN|953-178-097-8}}</ref> The second floor is in low Gothic style and was probably the work of Venetian masters, as it is reminiscent of the windows of the famous Venetian [[Ca' d'Oro|Palazzo Ca d'Oro]]. The final floor was built by Trifun Bokanić (1575–1609). On top of the bell tower there are four statues, the work of Venetian sculptor Alessandro Vittoria (1525–1608). In the centre of the facade, within a small round opening, there is the carved coat of arms of the most powerful King, Ludvic of Angevin dynasty.
==Description== Trogir cathedral is the most archaic example in the construction of interior arcades in Dalmatia with heavy elongated piers separating the two Gothic-ribbed aisles from the nave, vaulted later also in Gothic style in the 15th century,<ref name="Delalle">Ivo Delalle, Mirko Slade – Šilovič, Stanko Geič, ''Trogir: Small Touristic Monograph'', pg. 27, Studio HRG, Zagreb (1999), {{ISBN|953-97699-0-6}}</ref> three semi-circular apses and a vaulted interior above which rises the Campanile. Unfortunately, only one of the two planned towers (the southern), was raised. The cross vaults and the earlier terraces above the aisles are of Apulian influence.
A large '''vestibule''' was added in the 15th century and the artistically well-executed Gothic [[Rosette (window)|rosette]] on the western facade is from the same period. At the far end of the entrance hall there is a Gothic and Romanesque '''baptistery''' which was added to the cathedral in about 1467 by Andrija Aleši (1430–1504), a sculptor of Albanian origins and a pupil of Juraj Dalmatinac. The Gothic '''sacristy''' was added to the cathedral in the 15th century. The outside thick wall is divided by pilasters and pierced with arched opens.
===Romanesque portal=== The local architect and sculptor Master [[Radovan (master)|Radovan]] worked on the cathedral's gateway (main west portal) early in its construction. Most of the portal was carved by the master himself but some other hands are distinguishable, those of his pupils and followers. Finished and signed in 1240, it is a monumental and perhaps unique work of this great Croatian artist, of whom the inscription on the base of the lunette says: ''"the best of all in this artisanship"''.<ref name="Delalle"/>
In terms of its thematic concept, the portal is divided into two parts: upper and lower. The upper part shows scenes from the Gospels, that is, the life of Christ. On the lunette there is the scene of the Nativity, and inside the arch above the lunette there are angels looking adoringly at the scene. The lunette and this arch are the work of Master Radovan. Over them there is another arch which also shows scenes from the life of Christ. On the interior of the doorposts there are pictures showing the various works done during the different seasons of the year. Radovan also worked on the two small columns covered in reliefs. On the exterior doorpost the saints and apostles are represented; the interior of the same posts are decorated with figures of exotic animals and fantastic creatures like centaurs and mermaids. Human forms dominate the portal. Both the internal and external doorposts rest on the back of bearers bent over, who are also the work of Radovan himself. Beside the portal, standing on the backs of two lions, stand the figures of Adam and Eve.
Other significant artisans who worked on the building were Matija Gojković, [[Ivan Budislavić]], Grgur Vidov, and Petar Pozdanić in the 15th century.
The cathedral is part of the historic core of Trogir, which is a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]].<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/810/ UNESCO World Heritage Site: Trogir]</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:1240 portal Trogir.jpg|Portal of [[Radovan (master)|Radovan]] File:Cathedral of St. Lawrence, Trogir entrance detail (right side).JPG|Entrance detail (right side) File:Cathedral of St. Lawrence, Trogir entrance detail (left side).JPG|Entrance detail (left side) File:Trogir cathedral entrance detail 017.jpg|Entrance detail File:Mladen III Šubić - nadgrobna ploča u Trogirskoj katedrali.jpg|[[Mladen III Šubić of Bribir]] (*1315-†1348) gravestone in the Cathedral </gallery>
==See also== * [[Radovan (master)]] * [[Trogir]] * [[Culture of Croatia]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Cathedrals in Croatia}} {{World Heritage Sites in Croatia}} {{Landmarks in Dalmatia}}

{{about|the feminist newspaper|the newspaper section "Womanews" dedicated to women's issues|Chicago Tribune}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = WomaNews | image = [[File:WomaNews (April 1989 front page).jpg|257px|alt=Front page]] | caption = April 1989 front page | type = Monthly [[newspaper]] | format = | owners = | founder = | publisher = | editor = WomaNews Collective | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | seniorstaff = | staff = | foundation = 1979 | political = | language = | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = }}
'''''WomaNews''''' was a [[radical feminist]] [[newspaper]] that began in [[Gainesville, Florida]] in the 1970s before moving production to New York, New York.
==Purposes== Mainstream American newspapers addressed majority concerns and so different minority papers emerged in response to the need for a more comprehensive and multivocal approach to news. Women's sections in mainstream newspapers and women's newspapers provided a needed avenue for the dissemination of information and discussion of current concerns from and for women. The same is true for other minority newspapers, like the many [[African-American newspapers]] that covered human rights violations, oppression, and the beginnings of the [[Civil Rights Movement]], before mainstream newspapers offered regular or even-handed coverage.
==References== * {{cite book | last = Braden | first = Maria | title = She said what?: interviews with women newspaper columnists | publisher = University Press of Kentucky | location = Lexington, Kentucky | year = 2009 | isbn = 9780813193328 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=Se1Z6DU9KoAC&d Preview.] * {{cite book | last1 = Steiner | first1 = Linda | last2 = Chambers | first2 = Deborah | last3 = Fleming | first3 = Carole | author-link1 = Linda Steiner | title = Women and journalism | publisher = Routledge | location = London New York | year = 2004 | isbn = 9780203500668 }} [https://books.google.com/books?id=olAJxqGZ6VkC&dq Preview.]

{{news release|1=article|date=January 2015}} '''Writopia Lab''' is a non-profit<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | url = http://www.writopialab.org/transfer/501c3CertificationLetter.pdf|title=Letter from Inland Revenue Service confirming non-tax status | publisher = | date = | accessdate = 6 May 2013 }}</ref> creative writing program for kids and teens ages 4–18.
Founded in 2007<ref name=wapoPro /> by [[Rebecca Wallace-Segall]], Writopia integrates a student-centered methodology into the workshop, where each student sets his or her own goals with the guidance of the instructor, and is encouraged to finish a full piece of writing by the end of the workshop period. Most Writopia students attend workshops at Writopia's main locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Westchester, Washington DC,<ref name=wapoPro>{{cite news|last=Kelly|first=John|title=Once upon a time. . . young writers put on the prose|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/once-upon-a-time---young-writers-put-on-the-prose/2013/02/27/fb85e344-80f1-11e2-a350-49866afab584_story.html|accessdate=4 May 2013|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=27 February 2013}}</ref> Chicago, and Los Angeles. Workshops held at Writopia's main locations cost a fee on an honor-based sliding scale fee system. Writopia also runs free writing workshops offered throughout the [[New York Public Library]], including the Edenwald branch, the 115th Street branch, the Throg's Neck Library, the Francis Martin branch, and Clason's Point Library. Writopia also runs writing workshops for children who reside at [[Homes for the Homeless]] "inns."<ref name="www.icphusa.org">{{Cite web | last = Linek | first = Katie | title = Uncensored "The Write Stuff" | url = http://www.icphusa.org/PDF/uncensored/ICPH_UNCENSORED_5.3%20Fall_101514.pdf | publisher = | date = | accessdate = 12 November 2014 }}</ref> In addition, Writopia runs free college essay workshops in partnership with [[Bryant Park]]<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = Bryant Park Blog: Writing Workshops for Teens in the Reading Room | url = http://blog.bryantpark.org/2012/09/writing-workshops-for-teens-in-reading.html | publisher = | date = 12 September 2012 | accessdate = 6 May 2013 }}</ref> and with the Office of The Mayor/NYC Service. Writopia Lab serves as a community partner to [[Scholastic Art & Writing Awards|Scholastic Writing Awards]] in New York, and Writopia DC<ref>{{Cite web | last = Shapiro | first = Joseph | title = Amid Dropping Test Scores, Teen Writers' Creativity Soars : NPR | url = https://www.npr.org/2013/06/13/190351703/amid-dropping-test-scores-teen-writers-creativity-soars | publisher = NPR | date = June 13, 2013 | accessdate = 14 June 2013 }}</ref> and Writopia Westchester serve as affiliates to the Scholastic Writing Awards in those areas, administering the local recognition programs and ceremonies. Notable authors of Writopia Lab's Advisory Council include [[Nicole Krauss]],<ref>{{cite web|title = Nicole Krauss (final cut) - YouTube|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PyxvxSgODjU| publisher=Youtube.com|accessdate = 6 May 2013}}</ref> [[Susan Cain]], [[Steve Young (writer)]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Letterman Writer's Endorsement of Writopia Lab - YouTube|publisher=Youtube.com|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GEpjSidGcLc| accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref> and [[Stephen Dubner]].<ref>{{cite web|title= Stephen Dubner (final cut) - YouTube|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eldRio2mmB4|publisher =Youtube.com|accessdate=6 May 2013}}</ref>
==Worldwide Plays Festival== Writopia also runs the Worldwide Plays Festival each year, funded by [[David Letterman]]'s production company, [[Worldwide Pants]]. This monthly festival culminates in a week of [[off-broadway]] showcases.<ref>{{cite news|title=Writopia Lab's Worldwide Plays Festival show listing|url=http://theater.nytimes.com/show/116690/Writopia-Lab-s-Worldwide-Plays-Festival/overview|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=4 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Shaughnessy|first=Kristen|title=Weekend Feature: Young Playwrights Get Works Performed At Festival|url=http://www.ny1.com/content/161036/weekend-feature--young-playwrights-get-works-performed-at-festival|publisher=[[NY1]]|accessdate=4 May 2013|date=May 2012}}</ref><ref name="bxtimes.com">{{cite news|last=Cruz|first=David|title = Bronx Neighbors: Zania Cousins | url = http://bxtimes.com/stories/2013/18/18_profile_2013_05_02_bx.html|publisher=[[Bronx Times-Reporter]]|date = 8 May 2013 | accessdate = 10 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/10/13-year-old-playwright-awaits-his-big-night/#more-457376 | title=13-Year-Old Playwright Awaits His Big Night | date=11 May 2013 | accessdate=11 May 2013 | last=Hammill | first=Luke | newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> Each play chosen for production throughout the year was written by a student and then produced, directed and performed by theatre professionals. The festival was initiated by playwright Daniel Kitrosser in 2010 and won financial support from Worldwide Pants in 2011. Worldwide Pants donated $50,000 in 2011,<ref name=nytBarron>{{cite news|last=Barron|first=James|title=A Festival Where Playwriting Youth Is Served|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/05/16/a-festival-where-playwriting-youth-is-served/|accessdate=4 May 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=16 May 2011}}</ref> again in 2012, and $60,000 in 2013.
